Issues.Title: feat(router): Add ability to return UrlTree with `NavigationBehaviorOptions` from guards
Issues.Body:
Returning `UrlTree` from a guard was a convenient new feature added to
the `Router`. However, it does not have feature-parity with the old
`router.navigate(...); return false;` pattern. The most common use-case
for this feature is to redirect to a new page _without_ updating the URL
from the initially attempted navigation. For example, rendering a 404
page when the user does not have access privelages to a route.

Fixes #17004
Fixes #27148
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(router): Add ability to return UrlTree with `NavigationBehaviorOptions` from guards" (#45023)

Issues.Title: build(bazel): add bazel target for aio build
Issues.Body:
## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [ ] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [ ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->

- [ ] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [x] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:

## What is the new behavior?

Added a target for the aio project to be built by bazel. It does not yet include the generated content and is not used by the ci.

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No


<!-- If this PR contains a breaking change, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications below. -->


## Other information

Since architect requires the generated ngsw-config.json to be in the source root, I added a rule that will write to it and ensure it exists and is up to date (see [write_source_files](https://docs.aspect.build/aspect-build/bazel-lib/v0.4.3/docs/docs/write_source_files-docgen.html)). I chose to commit that file here, and that will be required once aio is fully built with bazel, but if you prefer I can leave it uncommitted for now---running the bazel build on aio will just pop out an error with a command to generate it.

Another decision I made was to move the ngsw-config.json out of `src/generated` to the root. This is because on each regular build the `generated` folder is deleted, and since I would need a `BUILD.bazel` file in there to stamp the `write_source_files`, it would be deleted and someone developing using the regular build would see the file missing in their git diff. Another option I could do is to make that deletion script a bit more picky about what it deletes.

Overall this is a first partial step in the migration.

Issues.Title: zone.js cause "Unable to preventDefault inside passive event listener invocation." "errors", if passive handler is added first
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

Don't known / other

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

There is issue with zone.js **addEventListener** patch. If you add listener with { passive: true } options first, same handler will be used for non-passive event listeners. As result calling event.preventDefault() causing error. Code example:

```
import 'zone.js';

document.addEventListener('mousemove', (ev) => {}, { passive: true });
document.addEventListener('mousemove', (ev) => {
  ev.preventDefault(); // throws error
});
```


### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

Demo - https://js-dtyss2.stackblitz.io/
Code - https://stackblitz.com/edit/js-dtyss2

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

_No response_

### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```
OS: win32 x64
Browser: Chrome 98

@zone.js        0.11.4
```

### Anything else?

_No response_

Issues.Title: Chain elementStart/elementEnd instructions
Issues.Body:
Split up into two commits to make it easier to review:

1. **refactor(compiler): rework instruction generation logic for improved flexibility**
Previously the logic for generating chained instructions was somewhat rigid, because we had to collect all of the calls ahead of time and then call one of the chained instruction helpers. This doesn't work for something like `elementStart`, because we have to descend into other elements that could add to the chain.

These changes refactor the code so that we collect the list of instructions in a flat array and we do the chaining only once at the end when we have the entire instruction set for the code block.

The new approach has the advantage of being (almost) entirely configuration-based via the `CHAINABLE_INSTRUCTIONS` array and being more flexible in allowing us to chain instructions that span across elements.

2. **perf(compiler): chain element start/end instructions** 

In templates with several levels of nested nodes, it's common for several `elementStart`/`elementEnd` instructions to show up in a row which can be optimized away.

These changes add chaining support for `elementStart`, `elementEnd`, `elementContainerStart` and `elementContainerEnd` to shave off some bytes when possible.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Chain elementStart/elementEnd instructions" (#44994)

Issues.Title: Custom validators on blur, not ran when blurring without value change
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

forms

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

It seems that custom validators do not run on blur when value is not changed. Which results in unwanted behavior.

**AS-IS**
I have a formGroup with multiple required fields (default angular required validator) and with updateOn: 'blur'. 
On the formGroup i have 1 validator which checks if any one of the fields is touched and invalid, then an error message should be displayed.
When initially entering the page, all fields are invalid, but none of them are touched --> no error message
When i enter a value in the first field and blur --> first field is valid and touch, other invalid and untouched --> no error message
BUT when i enter the next field, and immediately tab to the next without entering a value, the field is touched and invalid --> but still no error message is shown.

**EXPECTED**
In the last use-case above, 
 when i enter the next field, and immediately tab to the next without entering a value --> I expect the field to be invalid and touched and run my custom validator which then result in the error being displayed.


**CAUSE**
it seems that custom validators are only being ran on actual value change, and not on the actual blur functionality.
Even when not changing values, but just blurring, i do want the custom validator to run.


**SOLUTION FOR MYSELF (NOT IDEAL)**
Currently i use the (blur) event on each field to update the value and validity of that field only when an empty field is blurred.
I attached a link to a stackblitz where you can play around with the code.
In here you can see by the console log, that the custom validator is not being ran when click in and out a field.
I commented out the fix, you can just uncomment these lines in the .ts and .html file, and then you have my current solution.


In my opinion this should not be the expected behavior of running these validators on blur.
Open for discussion :) 



### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-iznhmk?file=src/app/app.component.ts

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

_No response_

### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
"@angular/animations": "^12.1.0",
    "@angular/common": "^12.1.0",
    "@angular/compiler": "^12.1.0",
    "@angular/core": "^12.1.0",
    "@angular/forms": "^12.1.0",
    "@angular/platform-browser": "^12.1.0",
    "@angular/platform-browser-dynamic": "^12.1.0",
```


### Anything else?

_No response_
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Custom validators on blur, not ran when blurring without value change" (#45015)

Issues.Title: HTML element remains disabled if FormControl is enabled
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

forms

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

Angular does not remove HTML disabled Attribute from input element when:

- input element is linked to formControl in disabled state
- user action causes that new instance of formControl is created (and replace the old one) in enabled state
- input element remains disabled (disabled attribure is not removed from HTML element)
(changing input element from enabled to disabled in this way works well)

Example:
For HTML template
`
<input [formControl]="testControl">
{{testControl.disabled}}
<button (click)="toggleDisable()">Toggle</button>

`

this toggle function cause the issue (after button click input remain disabled event if new form control is enabled):
`
 toggleDisable() {
    const newForm = new FormControl()
    newForm.setValue(this.testControl.value)
    if(this.testControl.disabled) {
      newForm.enable()
    } else  {
      newForm.disable()
    }
    this.testControl = newForm
  }
`

If I do not creaate new instance of form control (only modify the existing) - it work:
`
 toggleDisable() {
    if(this.testControl.disabled) {
      this.testControl.enable()
    } else  {
      this.testControl.disable()
    }
  }
`

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

_No response_

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
textarea (or any other input element) keeps disabled atribute when the associate FormControl is enabled
`
<textarea _ngcontent-cyo-c120="" ng-reflect-form="[object Object]" disabled class="ng-untouched ng-dirty ng-valid"></textarea>
`
```


### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular 12.2.2
```


### Anything else?

_No response_

Issues.Title: Allow imports with .js extension for package.json "type": "module" esm compatibility.
Issues.Body:
<!--🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅

Oh hi there! 😄

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅-->

# 🚀 Feature request

Reconsider https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/4591 which would require a webpack extension to allow developers to import modules using the '.js' file extension even though they are '.ts' files before compilation.

### Command (mark with an `x`)

<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ✍️edit: -->

- [ ] new
- [x] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] extract-i18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc

### Description

<!-- ✍️-->

I am working on a split back-end/front-end project and trying to use `"type":"module"` in both package.json files but I'm currently unable to update to es modules on the client side because webpack cannot resolve typescript modules if the import ends with '.js' instead.

See https://nodejs.org/api/esm.html#mandatory-file-extensions

Since TS 2.0, it's possible to :
`import { Something } from './something.js';// <- this is actually ./something.ts in the working directory.`

Module identifiers allow for .js extension

Before TypeScript 2.0, a module identifier was always assumed to be extension-less; for instance, given an import as import d from "./moduleA.js", the compiler looked up the definition of "moduleA.js" in ./moduleA.js.ts or ./moduleA.js.d.ts. This made it hard to use bundling/loading tools like SystemJS that expect URI's in their module identifier.

With TypeScript 2.0, the compiler will look up definition of "moduleA.js" in ./moduleA.ts or ./moduleA.d.ts.

It's also important to be compatible with ES6 modules, which require the .js extension, as <script type="module"></script> is standard in [evergreen browsers](https://caniuse.com/es6-module), and as for now TS doesn't provide an option to add the .js extension in transpiled files (see microsoft/TypeScript#13422).

### Describe the solution you'd like

<!-- ✍️-->

Add the resolve-typescript-plugin (or have an option to enable it) to the generated webpack config.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Currently I'm just running a split project where the `server` package requires '.js' extensions and the 'client' package does not. This is obviously not ideal.

Custom webpack builder can probably do this with this plugin: [resolve-typescript-plugin](https://www.npmjs.com/package/resolve-typescript-plugin) 

Nodejs can apparently be [configured to experimentally customize the resolution algorithm](https://nodejs.org/api/esm.html#esm_customizing_esm_specifier_resolution_algorithm)
<!-- ✍️-->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Allow imports with .js extension for package.json "type": "module" esm compatibility." (#22671)

Issues.Title: build: flip build script to bazel
Issues.Body:
This flips the cli build to use bazel, replacing the legacy build script with the bazel one.

Looking for careful feedback on the second commit where I stop running bazel clean before a release build. This is something I originally copied over from the angular project, but I can no longer reproduce the issue locally. I think that my use of `config_setting`s and `select`s with the release artifacts causes the build to correctly stamp artifacts without the need for a clean... but someone who understands this better should take a look.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: flip build script to bazel" (#22638)

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>angular/angular</summary>

### [`v14.0.0-next.2`](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/blob/HEAD/CHANGELOG.md#​1400-next2-2022-02-07)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/angular/angular/compare/14.0.0-next.1...14.0.0-next.2)

#### Breaking Changes

##### forms

-   Forms \[email] input coercion: forms \[email] input value will be considered as true if it is defined with any value rather than false and 'false'.
-   Objects with a length key set to zero will no longer validate as empty. This is technically a breaking change, since objects with a key `length` and value `0` will no longer validate as empty. This is a very minor change, and any reliance on this behavior is probably a bug anyway.

##### platform-browser

-   This change may cause a breaking change in unit tests that are implicitly depending on a specific number and sequence of change detections in order for their assertions to pass.
-   This tightens parameter types of `TransferState` usage, and is a minor breaking change which may reveal existing problematic calls. This may break invalid calls to `TransferState` methods.

##### router

-   The type of `initialUrl` is set to `string|UrlTree` but in reality,
    the `Router` only sets it to a value that will always be `UrlTree`.
    `initialUrl` is documented as "The target URL passed into the
    `Router#navigateByUrl()` call before navigation" but the value
    actually gets set to something completely different. It's set to the
    current internal `UrlTree` of the Router at the time navigation
    occurs. With this change, there is no exact replacement for the old value of
    `initialUrl` because it was enver intended to be exposed.
    `Router.url` is likely the best replacement for this.
    In more specific use-cases, tracking the `finalUrl` between successful
    navigations can also be used as a replacement.

Issues.Title: build: fix bazel build on windows
Issues.Body:
Add a missing toolchain that was causing the nodejs_binary target for ng_cli_schema to fail on windows. I encountered this while trying to flip the ci to build with bazel.

Caused this error: https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/angular/angular-cli/20529/workflows/7f1860fe-0296-49d0-8466-6b23d9347ff8/jobs/287310?invite=true#step-112-31
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: fix bazel build on windows" (#22666)

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): block Karma from starting until build is complete
Issues.Body:
This change is inspired by https://github.com/karma-runner/karma-chrome-launcher/issues/154#issuecomment-986661937 which blocks Karma from launching the browsers until the compilation is complete.

This is needed especially for large applications when using code-coverage where otherwise the users would have to fine-tune several Karma timeouts such as  `captureTimeout` for various environments.

Closes #22495
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): block Karma from starting until build is complete" (#22670)

Issues.Title: Branch coverage data is incorrect after upgrading to Angular 13
Issues.Body:
# 🐞 Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [X] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] extract-i18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: Angular 12 ### Description The coverage produced when running `ng test --code-coverage` is incorrect, it is missing branches that were previously counted. This applies to `if` that do not have an `else`: these used to be counted as two branches, and they are now counted as one. This artificially increases branch coverage. ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction Starting from a minimal reproduction repository (`ng new`), make the following changes: 1. Add `src/foo.ts`. Note that this function contains two branches to cover: the if, and the (non-explicitly written) else. ``` export function foo(n: number) { if (n % 2 === 0) { console.log('hello'); } } ``` 2. Add `src/foo.spec.ts`: ``` import { foo } from './foo'; describe('test', () => { it('test', () => { foo(2); }); }); ``` 3. Restrict the test suite to run only `foo.spec.ts` in `src/test.ts`: ``` const context = require.context('./', true, /foo\.spec\.ts$/); ``` 4. Launch the tests with code coverage: `npx ng test --code-coverage` 5. The output reports full coverage, of only one branch: ``` =============================== Coverage summary =============================== Statements : 100% ( 2/2 ) Branches : 100% ( 1/1 ) Functions : 100% ( 1/1 ) Lines : 100% ( 2/2 ) ``` For comparison, downgrading to Angular 12 and to Typescript 4.3.5 results in the correct coverage report, which is: ``` =============================== Coverage summary =============================== Statements : 100% ( 5/5 ) Branches : 50% ( 1/2 ) Functions : 100% ( 1/1 ) Lines : 100% ( 5/5 ) ``` ## 🌍 Your Environment Everything comes from the default app when running `ng new` 

Angular CLI: 13.2.2
Node: 16.13.2
Package Manager: npm 8.1.2
OS: linux x64

Angular: 13.2.1
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router

The loader API now provides a new `LoadingContext` object, which provides new features:

-   `importer` provides the resolved path of the parent sourcemap.
-   `source` allows the loader to change the resolved location of the transformed sourcemap or original source file.
-   `content` allows override the parent sourcemap's `sourcesContent` field for an original source file.

### [`v0.14.20`](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/blob/HEAD/CHANGELOG.md#​01420)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/compare/v0.14.19...v0.14.20)

-   Fix property mangling and keyword properties ([#​1998](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/issues/1998))

    Previously enabling property mangling with `--mangle-props=` failed to add a space before property names after a keyword. This bug has been fixed:

    ```js
    // Original code
    class Foo {
      static foo = {
        get bar() {}
      }
    }

    // Old output (with --minify --mangle-props=.)
    class Foo{statics={gett(){}}}

    // New output (with --minify --mangle-props=.)
    class Foo{static s={get t(){}}}
    ```

### [`v0.14.19`](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/blob/HEAD/CHANGELOG.md#​01419)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/compare/v0.14.18...v0.14.19)

-   Special-case `const` inlining at the top of a scope ([#​1317](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/issues/1317), [#​1981](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/issues/1981))

    The minifier now inlines `const` variables (even across modules during bundling) if a certain set of specific requirements are met:

    -   All `const` variables to be inlined are at the top of their scope
    -   That scope doesn't contain any `import` or `export` statements with paths
    -   All constants to be inlined are `null`, `undefined`, `true`, `false`, an integer, or a short real number
    -   Any expression outside of a small list of allowed ones stops constant identification

    Practically speaking this basically means that you can trigger this optimization by just putting the constants you want inlined into a separate file (e.g. `constants.js`) and bundling everything together.

    These specific conditions are present to avoid esbuild unintentionally causing any behavior changes by inlining constants when the variable reference could potentially be evaluated before being declared. It's possible to identify more cases where constants can be inlined but doing so may require complex call graph analysis so it has not been implemented. Although these specific heuristics may change over time, this general approach to constant inlining should continue to work going forward.

    Here's an example:

    ```js
    // Original code
    const bold = 1 << 0;
    const italic = 1 << 1;
    const underline = 1 << 2;
    const font = bold | italic | underline;
    console.log(font);

    // Old output (with --minify --bundle)
    (()=>{var o=1<<0,n=1<<1,c=1<<2,t=o|n|c;console.log(t);})();

    // New output (with --minify --bundle)
    (()=>{console.log(7);})();
    ```

</details>

Issues.Title: Local serving does not work following upgrade to Angular 13
Issues.Body:
# 🐞 Bug report - [ ] new - [ ] build - [x ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] extract-i18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Description I have two Angular applications in my project, a main app, then a much smaller app for testing our internal UI component library. It's also an NX monorepo. I've just upgraded to Angular 13 (using `nx migrate` and the prod builds and main application serve are all working as expected. Unfortunately, the small UI component app is not working with serve. Previously our script command in package.json used to use the `--base-href` flag, but now in Angular 13 this has been removed and gives message: > 'baseHref' is not found in schema So I have removed the `--base-href` flag from the command in package.json. I've tried adding the exact same config to the angular.json file in the root of the project, like this: ``` "build": { "options": { "baseHref": "/component-guide", // rest of config } } ``` But this has not worked. The actual serve command completes successfully, but when I try to hit my app in the browser at URL `localhost/component-guide` it just goes crazy and reloads like every 10 milliseconds (it is just reloading like crazy, the favicon is actually flashing, never seen anything like it) I also tried adding the same `baseHref` config to the project.json file in the apps/component-guide folder (and having it in both angular.json and project,json individually and at the same time). ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction I'm sorry, but there isn't a _minimal reproduction_ - my project is enormous and contains not just one but two separate applications. I can provide any additional information, or examples from my config files, but I cannot share the project as it is a commercial product. ## 🔥 Exception or Error Application reloads hundreds of times per second ## 🌍 Your Environment

Issues.Title: Allow proxy in ng-serve to proxy to local files
Issues.Body:
# 🚀 Feature request

### Command (mark with an `x`)

<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ✍️edit: -->

- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [X] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] extract-i18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc

Expanding on issue #6773

Since webpack 5.0.0 and module federation, pugins for Angular apps are now much more straightforward to develop.

However, serving these with `ng serve` is cumbersome because of the lack of static file serving support (it's common to want to load the plugins from the same webroot as the app).

Webpack devServer **does** support this via:

```
static: {
      directory: path.join(__dirname, 'whatever'),
      publicPath: '/whatever'
},
```

However, when supplied via `extraWebpackConfig` this configuration does not apply (presumably because it is overwritten by angular's own configuration).

### Describe the solution you'd like

Can we please have support for adding static serve paths to the dev server?

### Describe alternatives you've considered

It is of course possible to proxy requests through to a different server and have that serve the webroot, but this is clumsy and should be unnecessary.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Allow proxy in ng-serve to proxy to local files" (#22656)

Issues.Title: error TS5024: Compiler option 'files' requires a value of type Array
Issues.Body:
# 🚀 Feature request

### Command (mark with an `x`)

<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ✍️edit: -->

- [ ] new
- [X] build
- [X] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] extract-i18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc

### Description

Typescript supports semantics which specify if `include`, `exclude`, `files` and `types` (possibly others) will **replace** or **merge** when extending a base `tsconfig.json` file.

e.g this will blank the array that was set at a higher level:

```
"exclude": {
    "mode": "replace",
    "values": []
  }
```

However, angular-cli complains: "error TS5024: Compiler option 'files' requires a value of type Array"

### Describe the solution you'd like

Please add support for this semantic.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "error TS5024: Compiler option 'files' requires a value of type Array" (#22664)

Issues.Title: Version 13.2.2 breaks production build when using dynamic imports

# 🐞 Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] extract-i18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: 13.2.1 ### Description When running a production build with version 13.2.2, it fails with an error after chunk generation completes. This relates to using a dynamic import of a json file. The error is: `An unhandled exception occurred: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')` (see below for extended error) ng serve does not have this problem. ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction - A dynamic import of a json file: ```import(`../../../../../assets/animations/${this.animation}.json`).then(animation => {``` - causes the error (`Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')` - Because in function [`extractIdentifiedModule`](https://github.com/xz64/license-webpack-plugin/commit/55dd3f87c8f19338e45affec6f2271f75a0167ad#diff-1ceba7b65a6b2be17f78ef52a1cda37a99ce008020dabce02f3414141eb5261bR62-R81) the `directory` and `packageJson` are undefined The problem is caused by license-webpack-plugin@4.0.1, specifically the changes in commit https://github.com/xz64/license-webpack-plugin/commit/55dd3f87c8f19338e45affec6f2271f75a0167ad Also reported as bug to `license-webpack-plugin`: https://github.com/xz64/license-webpack-plugin/issues/119 ## 🔥 Exception or Error Error

<details>
<summary>evanw/esbuild</summary>

### [`v0.14.18`](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/blob/HEAD/CHANGELOG.md#​01418)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/compare/v0.14.17...v0.14.18)

-   Add the `--mangle-cache=` feature ([#​1977](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/issues/1977))

    This release adds a cache API for the newly-released `--mangle-props=` feature. When enabled, all mangled property renamings are recorded in the cache during the initial build. Subsequent builds reuse the renamings stored in the cache and add additional renamings for any newly-added properties. This has a few consequences:

    -   You can customize what mangled properties are renamed to by editing the cache before passing it to esbuild (the cache is a map of the original name to the mangled name).

    -   The cache serves as a list of all properties that were mangled. You can easily scan it to see if there are any unexpected property renamings.

    -   You can disable mangling for individual properties by setting the renamed value to `false` instead of to a string. This is similar to the `--reserve-props=` setting but on a per-property basis.

    -   You can ensure consistent renaming between builds (e.g. a main-thread file and a web worker, or a library and a plugin). Without this feature, each build would do an independent renaming operation and the mangled property names likely wouldn't be consistent.

    Here's how to use it:

    -   CLI

        ```sh
        $ esbuild example.ts --mangle-props=_$ --mangle-cache=cache.json
        ```

    -   JS API

        ```js
        let result = await esbuild.build({
          entryPoints: ['example.ts'],
          mangleProps: /_$/,
          mangleCache: {
            customRenaming_: '__c',
            disabledRenaming_: false,
          },
        })
        let updatedMangleCache = result.mangleCache
        ```

    -   Go API

        ```go
        result := api.Build(api.BuildOptions{
          EntryPoints: []string{"example.ts"},
          MangleProps: "_$",
          MangleCache: map[string]interface{}{
            "customRenaming_":   "__c",
            "disabledRenaming_": false,
          },
        })
        updatedMangleCache := result.MangleCache
        ```

    The above code would do something like the following:

    ```js
    // Original code
    x = {
      customRenaming_: 1,
      disabledRenaming_: 2,
      otherProp_: 3,
    }

    // Generated code
    x = {
      __c: 1,
      disabledRenaming_: 2,
      a: 3
    };

    // Updated mangle cache
    {
      "customRenaming_": "__c",
      "disabledRenaming_": false,
      "otherProp_": "a"
    }
    ```

-   Add `opera` and `ie` as possible target environments

    You can now target [Opera](https://www.opera.com/) and/or [Internet Explorer](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/internet-explorer.aspx) using the `--target=` setting. For example, `--target=opera45,ie9` targets Opera 45 and Internet Explorer 9. This change does not add any additional features to esbuild's code transformation pipeline to transform newer syntax so that it works in Internet Explorer. It just adds information about what features are supported in these browsers to esbuild's internal feature compatibility table.

-   Minify `typeof x !== 'undefined'` to `typeof x < 'u'`

    This release introduces a small improvement for code that does a lot of `typeof` checks against `undefined`:

    ```js
    // Original code
    y = typeof x !== 'undefined';

    // Old output (with --minify)
    y=typeof x!="undefined";

    // New output (with --minify)
    y=typeof x<"u";
    ```

    This transformation is only active when minification is enabled, and is disabled if the language target is set lower than ES2020 or if Internet Explorer is set as a target environment. Before ES2020, implementations were allowed to return non-standard values from the `typeof` operator for a few objects. Internet Explorer took advantage of this to sometimes return the string `'unknown'` instead of `'undefined'`. But this has been removed from the specification and Internet Explorer was the only engine to do this, so this minification is valid for code that does not need to target Internet Explorer.

</details>

See https://github.com/babel/babel/pull/14209 for more context.

Issues.Body:
<!--🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

# 🚀 Feature request

<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ✍️edit: -->

- [x] new
- [x] build
- [x] serve
- [x] test
- [x] e2e
- [x] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [x] lint
- [ ] extract-i18n
- [x] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc

### Description

I have a mono repository and I want to split my `angular.json` into separate files.

So that I can have something like this:

```
{
  "version": 2,
  "projects": {
    "module-auth": "packages/module/auth",
    "module-core": "packages/module/core",
    "ui-button": "packages/ui/button"
  }
}
```

**My current `angular.json` file has 119 lines of code which is 100 % going to be unmaintainable in the future.** Keep in mind that what I have is a pet project and it is nowhere near thousands of lines of code that production applications might have.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Make the JSON configuration 1:1 with what NX does: https://nx.dev/configuration/projectjson#workspace-json

Issues.Title: New app generation requires git
Issues.Body:
# 🐞 Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [x] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] extract-i18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: .... 11, although was also running into bug with `ng new` there - https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/21326 ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... When I run `ng new ` on a system without git installed, it fails. I don't think git should be a requirement for a new app generation (I don't believe it's a documented requirement). New app generation should also be deterministic, not relying on a git repo that could change without notice. ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction In a docker container: ``` FROM centos:7 USER root RUN yum update -y RUN echo "Installing NVM" && \ curl -o- https://raw.githubusercontent.com/nvm-sh/nvm/v0.39.0/install.sh | bash && \ export NVM_DIR="$HOME/.nvm" && \ [ -s "$NVM_DIR/nvm.sh" ] && \. "$NVM_DIR/nvm.sh" RUN echo "Installing Node" && \ nvm install 16 && \ nvm alias default 16 && \ nvm use 16 && \ mkdir -pv /opt/node && \ cp -rf ${HOME}/.nvm/versions/node/v*/* /opt/node && \ export PATH="/opt/node/bin:${PATH}" RUN echo "Installing Angular" && \ npm install -g @angular/cli@12.2.16 && \ RUN echo "Upgrading npm." && \ npm install -g npm@8.4.0 RUN node --version && \ npm --version && \ ng --version ENTRYPOINT [ "sleep" ] CMD [ "86400" ] ``` open up a bash session in the container, and run `ng new mytestapp`: ``` $ ng new mytestapp ? Would you like to add Angular routing? Yes ? Which stylesheet format would you like to use? CSS CREATE mytestapp/README.md (1056 bytes) CREATE mytestapp/.editorconfig (274 bytes) CREATE mytestapp/.gitignore (604 bytes) CREATE mytestapp/angular.json (3057 bytes) CREATE mytestapp/package.json (1073 bytes) CREATE mytestapp/tsconfig.json (783 bytes) CREATE mytestapp/.browserslistrc (703 bytes) CREATE mytestapp/karma.conf.js (1426 bytes) CREATE mytestapp/tsconfig.app.json (287 bytes) CREATE mytestapp/tsconfig.spec.json (333 bytes) CREATE mytestapp/src/favicon.ico (948 bytes) CREATE mytestapp/src/index.html (295 bytes) CREATE mytestapp/src/main.ts (372 bytes) CREATE mytestapp/src/polyfills.ts (2820 bytes) CREATE mytestapp/src/styles.css (80 bytes) CREATE mytestapp/src/test.ts (788 bytes) CREATE mytestapp/src/assets/.gitkeep (0 bytes) CREATE mytestapp/src/environments/environment.prod.ts (51 bytes) CREATE mytestapp/src/environments/environment.ts (658 bytes) CREATE mytestapp/src/app/app-routing.module.ts (245 bytes) CREATE mytestapp/src/app/app.module.ts (393 bytes) CREATE mytestapp/src/app/app.component.css (0 bytes) CREATE mytestapp/src/app/app.component.html (24617 bytes) CREATE mytestapp/src/app/app.component.spec.ts (1082 bytes) CREATE mytestapp/src/app/app.component.ts (213 bytes) ⠹ Installing packages (npm)... ✔ Packages installed successfully. /bin/sh: git: command not found ``` ## 🔥 Exception or Error

Purpose of feature is to add `ng lint` functionality to watch cycle of `ng serve` and `ng build --watch` commands. Right now, I can set up linter in IDE, but it only lints file I am currently working on.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Issues.Title: Yarn install 3 slower after upgrade to 13.2.0
Issues.Body:
# 🐞 Bug report Yarn install takes 3x more time to finish installation and move on ### Command (mark with an `x`) yarn install ### Is this a regression? yes: works normal till version 13.2.0 ### Description Upgrading from 13.1.4 to 13.2.0 yarn takes ~9-10 minutes On 13.1.4 it takes 2-3 minutes for our repo ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction Not sure if that can be reproduced but here is a list of Issues.Title: @angular-devkit/build-angular using ora spinner with default "stdErr" stream can break test environments
Issues.Body:
# 🐞 Bug report ### Command - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [X] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] extract-i18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? This was working in Angular <=10 because the "ora" package was not used to create a beautiful spinner in the console stream. ### Description The ora spinner is using **process.stderr** as default stream which causes some test runners to fail the entire test execution because there was something written to the stdErr output. This behavior can be changed to use **process.stdout** instead which should be enough for this kind of logging. ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction using e.g. karma 6.3.12 ng test any-library-you-want-to ## 🔥 Exception or Error There is no actual issue, but this is what the spinner is used for in the test command: 
\ Generating browser application bundles (phase: building)...
√ Browser application bundle generation complete.
I'm sure the spinner is used in other commands, too. But for the most uses cases (e.g. local development) writing to strErr stream is not relevant except for testing strategies. An issue in the stdErr stream could cause test runners to declare the run as failed even all tests succeeded. ## 🌍 Your Environment 
Angular CLI: 11.2.0
Node: 14.18.2
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 11.2.0

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1102.18
@angular-devkit/build-angular   0.1102.18
@angular-devkit/core            11.2.0
@angular-devkit/schematics      11.2.18
@schematics/angular             11.2.18
@schematics/update              0.1102.0
ng-packagr                      11.2.0
rxjs                            6.6.3
typescript                      4.0.8
**Anything else relevant?** This affects all versions of Angular 11+

Issues.Title: fix(material/datepicker): update active date on focusing a cell
Issues.Body:
When a a date cell on the calendar recieves focus, set the active date
to that cell. This ensures that the active date matches the date with
browser focus.

Previously, we set the active date on keydown and click, but that was
problematic for screenreaders. That's because many screenreaders trigger
a focus event instead of a keydown event when using screenreader
specific navigation (VoiceOver, Chromevox, NVDA).

Note that this is the second attempt at this. First attempt was #24279,
which was reverted in #24380 due to an internal issue.

Fixes #23483
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(material/datepicker): update active date on focusing a cell" (#24384)

Issues.Title: bug(VirtualScroll): Safari 15.4 breaks virtual scroll; unable to scroll the list
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

Safari 15.4 is the next version of Safari and is currently in beta. You can use it on macOS by installing Safari Technology Preview 15.4. You can use it on iOS by installing iOS 15.4 Beta.

CDK virtual scroll lists will no longer scroll on 15.4 although they work fine on 15.3 and previous versions.

_This is very arguably an issue in WebKit 15.4 and not something to be fixed in the CDK itself. I wanted to at least help the CDK maintainers and others who might begin running into this issue have some awareness as to what's going on. I have opened an issue with WebKit [here](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=236260). If there are no changes to be made to the CDK, feel free to close this issue if desired._

### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open https://material.angular.io/cdk/scrolling/examples on Safari 15.4.
  - Safari 15.4 is the next version of Safari and is currently in beta. You can use it on macOS by installing Safari Technology Preview 15.4. You can use it on iOS by installing iOS 15.4 Beta.
2. When you try scrolling the examples you'll see the virtual list will not scroll at all.
  - When using macOS, you'll see the vertical scrollbar no longer appears. You can't scroll using a mouse scroll wheel either.
  - When using iOS, touch-based scrolling doesn't work.

If you open the same examples on Safari 15.3 (current stable version), the lists scroll and the vertical scrollbar is present on macOS.


### Expected Behavior

Virtual scroll lists can scroll on Safari 15.4 like they do on Safari 15.3.

### Actual Behavior

Virtual scroll lists do not scroll on Safari 15.4.

### Environment

(This is inferred from the StackBlitz examples for the examples at https://material.angular.io/cdk/scrolling/examples .)

- Angular: 13.0.3
- CDK/Material: 13.2.0
- Browser(s): Safari 15.4
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOS, iOS
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "bug(VirtualScroll): Safari 15.4 breaks virtual scroll; unable to scroll the list" (#24373)

Tried running the "Highlighting specific dates" example from https://material.angular.io/components/datepicker/overview on Stackblitz. It would not highlight. Also, tried downloading the example and updating to latest release. It still did not work.

Expected

Actual

Steps to reproduce:
1. Download [angular-date-class-filter-13.zip](https://github.com/angular/components/files/8028249/angular-date-class-filter-13.zip)

3. npm install
4. ng serve --port 4000
5. Open browser to port 4000
6. Click calendar icon

Neither day is highlighted.

Issues.Title: fix(material/sidenav): prevent focus from entering hidden sidenav if child element has a visibility
Issues.Body: This is a similar fix that we've made for other components. Usually we set `visibility: hidden` on the sidenav which is enough to prevent the user from tabbing into it, however one of the children could override it with `visibility: visible`. These changes add an extra `display: none` on top which will prevent such issues. This has come up on AIO recently https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/44990.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(material/sidenav): prevent focus from entering hidden sidenav if child element has a visibility" (#24376)

Issues.Title: bug(Theming Angular Material): Custom typography not applied to standard typography levels in mat.core-theme() or all-component-themes()
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

Tried to change the font-family so that e.g. body-1 everywhere has font family Arial.
But it only changed the font-family in mat components, not outside in normal divs.

```
$my-typography: mat.define-typography-config(
  $font-family: 'Arial',
);
$my-theme: mat.define-light-theme((
  typography: $my-typography,
  color: (
    primary: $dicey-primary,
    accent: $dicey-accent,
    warn: $dicey-warn,
  ))
);
@include mat.all-component-themes($my-theme);
```

Similar problem was reported here, but not solved: https://github.com/angular/components/issues/23683#issue-1015421891

-----------------------

It works when I do it with all-component-typographies:

```
$my-typography: mat.define-typography-config(
  $font-family: 'Arial',
);
@include mat.all-component-typographies($my-typography);
```


### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1.  Add custom theme with typography
2.  See if body tag font-family changes


### Expected Behavior

Bodys font family changes to custom font family

### Actual Behavior

The body font family is standard Roboto

### Environment

- Angular: 13.1.2
- CDK/Material: 13.1.1
- Browser(s): Firefox
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 11
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(Theming Angular Material): Custom typography not applied to standard typography levels in mat.core-theme() or all-component-themes()" (#24370)
